metadata.title: Aggregate Weight & Tonnage Calculator
metadata.description: Estimate aggregate mass and tonnage from measured volume or from area × depth, with options for density, moisture, and compaction. Includes common unit choices and authoritative references for best-practice values and measurement confidence.

from_volume.label: Calculate from Volume
from_volume.description: Enter a measured volume and material properties (density, moisture, compaction) to compute mass and different tonnage units.

from_area_depth.label: Calculate from Area × Depth
from_area_depth.description: Compute volume from length × width × depth and convert to mass using density, moisture and compaction factors.

introduction: This calculator estimates the mass and tonnage of construction aggregates from either a measured volume or area × depth. Use the density input to reflect the specific material (e.g., crushed stone, gravel, sand) and adjust moisture and compaction factors to match site conditions.

Default density values are a starting point; for procurement, specification, or billing use the density and acceptance tolerances from lab tests or supplier data. For unit consistency and conversions this tool uses SI base units (metres, cubic metres, kilograms) and converts to common industry tonnage units.
methodology: Choose a method: (A) supply a measured volume and its unit, or (B) provide length, width and depth (all in metres) to compute volume.
Convert the provided volume to cubic metres. Optionally adjust for compaction/swell using the compaction factor.
Multiply volume (m³) by density (kg/m³). Apply moisture as a percentage increase in mass if required. Present results in kilograms, metric tonnes, short tons (US), and pounds.
how_is_calculated: Volume (m³) from measured volume: volume_m³ = volume_value × volume_unit_multiplier
Volume (m³) from area × depth: volume_m³ = length_m × width_m × depth_m × compaction_factor
Metric tonnes (t) = Mass (kg) / 1000; Short tons (US) ≈ Mass (kg) / 907.18474; Pounds (lb) = Mass (kg) × 2.20462262

faqs.question: Where should I get the density value for my aggregate?
faqs.answer: Use laboratory test results (specific gravity and bulk density) from your supplier or project laboratory. If lab data are unavailable, use published ranges for the material class and then confirm with testing. Government and university materials resources provide typical ranges for common aggregates.

faqs.question: How does moisture affect the estimate?
faqs.answer: Moisture increases mass by adding water weight. This calculator approximates that effect by scaling density by (1 + moisture_percent/100). For high-precision billing, measure moisture content by oven-dry or standard field methods and apply laboratory corrections.

faqs.question: What is a compaction factor and when should I change it?
faqs.answer: Compaction/swell factors account for the change in in-place volume vs. delivered loose volume (bulking or consolidation). Use project-specific compaction factors from specifications or test results; typical values are around 1.0 for compacted-in-place equals delivered volume, >1 for swell (loose > compacted), and <1 for consolidation.

faqs.question: How accurate are the unit conversions and formulas?
faqs.answer: Unit conversions follow SI-consistent constants (e.g., 1 yd³ = 0.764554858 m³; 1 ft³ = 0.0283168466 m³) and mass conversions use standard definitions (1 kg = 2.20462262 lb). For metrological traceability consult NIST guidance on units and measurement practice.

faqs.question: How should I handle tolerances for procurement or acceptance?
faqs.answer: Specify acceptance tolerances and test frequency in your contract. Use laboratory-determined bulk densities and moisture corrections to convert field-tested volumes to delivered mass for billing. Where regulatory compliance matters, follow relevant agency specifications and standards.

faqs.question: Can I use this for materials other than aggregates?
faqs.answer: Yes — enter an appropriate density (kg/m³) for the material. Confirm that density and moisture behavior are appropriate for the material class before applying results in engineering or commercial decisions.

faqs.question: What measurement best practices improve confidence?
faqs.answer: Use calibrated volume-measurement equipment (measuring tapes, laser distance meters), a representative sampling plan for density and moisture, and laboratory methods for bulk density. Document measurement methods and calibration to support traceability.
